SubTopics: Answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Which sentence from the passage tells why Mary Cassatt wanted to study art?

A.Choice: “Mary’s early childhood was spent in Pennsylvania in traditional communities where, in those days, girls were taught to play the piano, paint china, or draw.”

Key.Rationale: This option is related to art but does not tell why Mary Cassatt wanted to study art.

B.Choice: “Perhaps this is why, when Mary told him of her wish to go to Paris to study to become an artist, he was very upset.”

Key.Rationale: This option is related to art but does not tell why Mary Cassatt wanted to study art.

C.Choice: “Her passion for art was more important to her than doing the ‘proper’ thing.”

Key.Rationale: This option describes how much she valued art in comparison to other things.

D.Choice: “So a day came when she packed her trunks and suitcases and prepared to cross the ocean to go to Europe where she could begin to work toward her goal.”

Key.Rationale: This option is related to art but does not tell why Mary Cassatt wanted to study art.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:Mary would overcome the artistic problems faced by every aspiring artist, in addition to the o͟b͟s͟t͟a͟c͟l͟e͟s placed in her way by a male-dominated art world.
What does the word o͟b͟s͟t͟a͟c͟l͟e͟s mean as used in the sentence?

Key.Rationale: The word “obstacles” has the meaning of “challenges” in the context of this sentence.
This option does not present the correct meaning for “obstacles” and does not make sense in the given context.
This option does not present the correct meaning for “obstacles” and does not make sense in the given context.
This option does not present the correct meaning for “obstacles” and does not make sense in the given context.

Content: Which words from the sentence support the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

Key.Rationale: “Overcome” supports the definition of “obstacles” as challenges.
“Problems” supports the definition of “obstacles” as challenges.
This option does not support the correct meaning of “obstacles” in the given context.
This option does not support the correct meaning of “obstacles” in the given context.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of word relationships and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:In time, even Mary’s father grew to understand her ambition and came to believe she had made the right choices in her life.
What does the phrase “grew to understand” mean?

Key.Rationale: The passage describes how Mary’s father slowly accepted her choices.
This option does not make sense in the context of the passage.
This option does not make sense in the context of the passage.
This option does not make sense in the context of the passage.

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Based on the passage, which part of Mary Cassatt’s life probably had the most effect on her?

Key.Rationale: Mary Cassatt may not have known of Degas’ comment.
It was living in Pennsylvania that prevented her from becoming an artist.
Cassatt’s father becoming successful did not affect her becoming an artist.

D.Choice: She decided to move to Europe.

Key.Rationale: It was living in Europe that allowed her to become a professional artist.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Sturcture/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the logical connection between particular sentences and paragraphs to support specific points in a text (e.g., comparison, cause/effect, first/second/third in a sequence).
Content: How are the paragraphs mainly used to present information about Mary Cassatt?

A.Choice: They show how her art changed over time.

Key.Rationale: This option is not the main text structures used in the passage.

B.Choice: They describe the important events in her life.

Key.Rationale: The passage uses chronological order to relay events from Mary Cassatt’s life.

C.Choice: They compare her to other famous women.

Key.Rationale: This option is not the main text structures used in the passage.

D.Choice: They tell the steps she used to create her art.

Key.Rationale: This option is not the main text structures used in the passage.

SubTopics: Answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: What did Mary Cassatt do that might make her a hero to others? Use details from the passage to support your answer.

SubTopics: Use spelling patterns and generalizations (e.g., word families, position-based spellings, syllable patterns, ending rules, meaningful word parts) in writing words.
Content: Which sentence has a spelling mistake?

Key.Rationale: This option is a word that is spelled correctly.

B.Choice: He can carry the box by himself.

Key.Rationale: This option is a word that is spelled correctly.

C.Choice: You can be successful if you try hard.

Key.Rationale: This option is a word that is spelled correctly.

D.Choice: The toy broak when it fell off the chair.

Key.Rationale: “Broak” should be spelled as “broke.”

SubTopics: Form and use comparative and superlative adjectives and adverbs, and choose between them depending on what is to be modified.
Content: :box:We weighed the gray rocks and the red rocks. We found that the red rocks were _____________ than the gray rocks.
Which word or words correctly fill the blank?

Key.Rationale: The weight of “gray rocks” is being compared to the weight of “red rocks.”
The adjective “heavy” has two syllables and ends with a “y,” which makes the comparative form of the word “heavier.” This option is not correct since it does not follow this convention.
The adjective “heavy” has two syllables and ends with a “y,” which makes the comparative form of the word “heavier.” This option is not correct since it does not follow this convention.
The adjective “heavy” has two syllables and ends with a “y,” which makes the comparative form of the word “heavier.” This option is not correct since it does not follow this convention.

Content: Which sentence shows the correct way to punctuate the address?

A.Choice: Aunt Joan lives at 143, Spring Street, Dayton, Ohio.

Key.Rationale: This option fails to separate each component with a comma.

B.Choice: Aunt Joan lives at 143 Spring Street, Dayton, Ohio.

Key.Rationale: A comma is needed to separate each component of an address; a comma should be used after the street name and after the city.

C.Choice: Aunt Joan lives at 143, Spring Street, Dayton Ohio.

Key.Rationale: This option fails to separate each component with a comma.

D.Choice: Aunt Joan lives at, 143 Spring Street Dayton, Ohio.

Key.Rationale: This option fails to separate each component with a comma.

SubTopics: Produce simple, compound, and complex sentences.
Content: Which sentence is a compound sentence?

A.Choice: Amy will practice soccer after school today.

Key.Rationale: This option is a simple sentence.

B.Choice: Scott found his baseball cap on top of the table.

Key.Rationale: This option is a simple sentence.

C.Choice: We knocked on the door, and our neighbor answered it.

Key.Rationale: This option has two independent clauses joined together with a conjunction.

D.Choice: Once it stops raining, we can go outside to ride our bikes.

Key.Rationale: This option is a complex sentence; a complex sentence has one independent clause and at least one dependent clause. In this sentence, “once it stops raining” is the dependent clause.
